page.title: 06LOCAL HISTORY-GREAT LUMLEY.
page.content: {LUMLEY} developed from a tiny,farming hamlet when the pits were sunk. It consisted of a long High Street and various colliery-owned terraces,whose names reflected residents' jobs, e.g. Sinkers'Row, Slaters'Row. The houses lacked baths and flush toilets.There were shops,a bakery,a doctor's,Duck's Hospital, a National School,an engine house ( a donkey engine pulled full trucks to the coal depot ), three chapels, a church and thirteen pubs. There were several farms. In the 1920's, better housing for pit officials came to Lumley. Though from the 1920's - 1960's, the pits began to close, housing expanded and three farms disappeared. Today Lumley is not the mining community it once was (though the brickworks still use local opencast shale),but a dormitory village. {J.Patterson.
